keyTakeAways: A fire broke out at Hungary's primary oil refinery in Százhalombatta on Monday night, with no injuries reported.
The cause of the fire is under investigation, but emergency protocols were followed and operations are being restarted gradually.
Hungary's only major crude-processing facility, the Danube Refinery, primarily processes oil from Russia — a rare practice in the EU after the 2022 Ukraine war.
The EU has implemented an embargo on Russian oil and plans to completely halt Russian oil and gas imports by 2027, yet Hungary has maintained and even increased its Russian oil imports.
Prime Minister Viktor Orbán confirmed that Hungary’s fuel supply remains secure and emphasized the thorough investigation of the incident.
Air quality around the refinery was continuously monitored, and no readings above health limits were detected.
The facility’s internal fire brigade was first on the scene, with support from professional firefighters from nearby cities.
Eyewitnesses reported visible flames and smoke from several kilometers away, indicating the scale and visibility of the incident.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A fire broke out overnight at Hungary’s main oil refinery, the Danube Refinery in Százhalombatta, with no injuries reported. The incident, occurring during a period when the European Union has been phasing out Russian energy imports since 2022, highlights Hungary’s continued reliance on Russian oil — a rare practice in the bloc. Authorities confirmed emergency protocols were followed, operations are being restored, and air quality remains safe. Prime Minister Viktor Orbán reassured the public that fuel supplies are secure, while the cause of the fire remains under investigation. The fire underscores Hungary’s strategic divergence from EU energy policy, raising concerns about energy security and geopolitical resilience in the face of ongoing sanctions against Russia.
title: Fire at Hungary’s Main Oil Refinery Sparks Energy Security Concerns Amid EU Shift Away from Russian Oil
